title.narrative: Provision of life saving trauma care and psychological first aid services to conflict affected population in hard to reach and under-served areas of Kunduz Province.

description.narrative:
Johanniter (JUH) will jointly implement the project with implementing partner Just for Afghan Capacity and Knowledge (JACK). JUH as lead partner will lead over all project implementation amp will be involved in field monitoring amp reporting responsibilities amp build the capacity of the national sub-implementing partner in all aspects of the project delivery. The project areas proposed in Kunduz province consists of conflict affected areas in Imam Sahib, Khan Abad, Dasht-e-Archi, ChahrDara amp Qala-e-zal. which are considered as Hard to Reach Districts by REACH and HRP 2020. The project will cover 650 villages with catchment population of 212,623 through the following interventions: a) 5 First Aid Trauma Post (FATPs) and Rapid Response Teams (RRTs, with ambulance and a trained first responders) which will be part of the existing Health Facilities (HFs) identified to provide life- saving first aid trauma care. Rapid Response Teams will be placed at each of the FATPs with one ambulance each to stabilize and evacuate casualties from the area of fighting to the nearby FATP or upper level HF based on initial assessment b) Provision of Physiotherapy services by male and female physiotherapist to People with Special Needs (PSNs)/PWDs and follow up of post- surgery trauma cases c) provision of psychological first aid through psychosocial counselling to those with symptoms of PTSD d) staff capacity building to enhance their capacities to respond to emergency situations.
Proposed project is in line with the SOs of the Humanitarian Response Plan of 2018-2021 amp the Health Cluster Objectives. Proposed FATPs will have gender balanced staffing to ensure access of women amp girls. All project staff to be recruited will undergo basic trainings as per the MoPH guidelines and NTA scales which meets the requirements of the project. The project will be for 12 months duration with 1-month inception phase. The JUH Country Office will provide technical support to the field staff amp sub-implementing partner, conduct capacity building activities of the project, continuously monitor project activities through dedicated MampE and capacity building person at the field supported by Programme and technical unit, M amp E and and a dedicated Logistics Officer who will be seconded to the sub implementing partner for initial phase and Inclusion team at Kabul Country Office. JUH will support procurement for the project with assigned main office person to the field during the initial quarter of the project and subsequent visits. JACK who is the sub-implementing partner is currently implementing BPHS programme in the province and thus has added value in integrating the FATPs and RRTs into their health facilities and can support in access and coordination. Both JUH amp JACK will coordinate with clusters at the national amp provincial level for the effective implementation of the project. For project reporting, the sub implementing partner will submit monthly report to Johanniter and interim report (technical and financial) to be submitted to donor as per the agreement. A monthly program and finance meeting with JACK will be organized and facilitated by Johanniter to review the progress of the project activities and project expenditures. All field level reports will be compiled and shared with the concerned stakeholders and the data is secured and follow Do No Harm Principles.
Both JUH and JACK will ensure that safe guards for PSEA in all the programme implementation are in place and ensure beneficiary participate in all phases of implementation. Regular risk analysis will be carried out as these FATPs are functioning in HTR locations and will have access strategy worked out..
